user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_register_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_register_generic(struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem)
{
	/* Make sure that we can be found. */
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);

	/* Statically registered shmem regions cannot have a destructor. */
	metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);

	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
			    &shmem->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_register_generic:
#define metal_assert(cond) metal_sys_assert(cond)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
				    &shmem->node);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call to metal_list_add_tail(...) is reachable whenever the incoming shmem pointer satisfies the asserted conditions (shmem->name non-NULL and non-empty, and shmem->io.ops.close == NULL). The provided macro maps metal_assert to metal_sys_assert(cond), which may abort only when cond is false; it does not make the subsequent code intrinsically unreachable. Therefore, there is no guaranteed-unreachable code in this fragment. (Only if metal_sys_assert were implemented to unconditionally abort or never return regardless of cond would the call become unreachable.)
